docs.lead_paragraph: In a vast public education campaign, the biggest in the 34-year history of Medicare, the Federal Government is mailing handbooks this month to the 39 million Medicare beneficiaries to try to guide them through the increasingly complicated world of health care. Backed up by toll-free telephone service, (800) 633-4227, an expanding Internet site (www.medicare.gov) and outreach efforts with more than 200 local and national groups, the new campaign is intended to aid an aging population that experts say is often ill-equipped to handle the brave new world of health care choices envisioned by Congress.

headline.main: Extensive Effort Seeks to Clarify Medicare Maze

docs.abstract: Federal Government mails handbooks to 39 million Medicare beneficiaries to try to guide them through inceasingly complicated world of health care; new campaign, biggest in 34-year history of Medicare, includes toll-free telephone service, expanding Internet site and outreach efforts with more than 200 local and national groups; it is intended to aid aging population that experts say is often ill-equipped to handle new world of health care choices envisioned by Congress; challenge facing new campaign is daunting; many experts say there is significant confusion among elderly about costs and benefits of various health plans (M)
docs.snippet: In a vast public education campaign, the biggest in the 34-year history of Medicare, the Federal Government is mailing handbooks this month to the 39 million Medicare beneficiaries to try to guide them through the increasingly complicated world of...

docs.lead_paragraph: JENNA PAXTON is an educated consumer. Never, before last year, had she hesitated to toss a store-brand food into her shopping cart to shave her grocery bill. Like many Americans, she buys cheaper generic drugs instead of the brand names, too. But during a routine trip last year down aisle 16A of an H.E.B. supermarket in Austin, Tex., she hesitated at buying a product she had never thought of before: generic infant formula. The idea of saving $3 a can piqued her interest. Still, her first child, Aaron, had started out on Similac, the national brand known to generations of parents. And when her second son, Cameron, was born, she stayed loyal.

headline.main: Formula Fight: A Generic Vs. the Giants

docs.abstract: Article on generic brand baby forumlas, which are just now beginning to be stocked on supermarket and drugstore shelves across US; generic formula represents substantial savings to parents and potential cash cow to retailers; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: An operation that appears to have restored fertility to a young woman whose ovaries had been removed has offered hope to thousands of other young women facing infertility brought on by cancer treatment or benign conditions like ovarian cysts. The procedure has also touched off speculation -- some of it farfetched, scientists say -- about whether ovarian transplants might one day be used to help women ward off menopause indefinitely and have babies well into their golden years.

headline.main: Ballerina's Ovarian Tissue Transplant Gives Hope to Other Young Women Facing Infertility

docs.abstract: Margaret Lloyd-Hart, 30-year-old ballerina, appears to have had her fertility restored after ovarian tissue that was removed from her and frozen at age 28 is reimplanted; operation may offer hope of fertility to thousands of other young women who face chemotherapy for cancer or who, like Lloyd-Hart, suffer from benign conditions like ovarian cysts; Dr Kutluk Oktay, surgeon, dismisses speculation that procedure could be used to stop menopause in older women or that it can be done for women with ovarian cancer; photos (M)
